title: Haptic example
text:
Intro
This web page provides a comprehensive guide on how to create and play haptic feedback on a Teslasuit device. The page is structured to help developers understand the process of initializing the Teslasuit API, connecting to a device, accessing the Haptic subsystem, and playing haptic touches.

title: Haptic example
text:
Code for Haptic Touch
import time
import _setup_sys_path

1from teslasuit_sdk import ts_api
2import teslasuit_sdk.subsystems.ts_haptic
3from teslasuit_sdk.ts_mapper import TsBone2dIndex

4TOUCH_DURATION_MS = 3000

def main():
    try:
5        print("Initialize API")
        api = ts_api.TsApi()

6        device = api.get_device_manager().get_or_wait_last_device_attached()
7        player = device.haptic
8        mapper = api.mapper

9        print("Setup channels to play and touch parameters")
        layout = mapper.get_haptic_electric_channel_layout(device.get_mapping())
10        bones = mapper.get_layout_bones(layout)
11        channels = mapper.get_bone_contents(bones[TsBone2dIndex.RightUpperArm.value])
12        params = player.create_touch_parameters(100, 40, 150)

13        print("Create touch and play")
        playable_id = player.create_touch(params, channels, TOUCH_DURATION_MS)
14        player.play_playable(playable_id)

15        print("Wait until playback finished...")
        time.sleep(TOUCH_DURATION_MS / 1000)
16        print("Finished")

17    except (KeyboardInterrupt, SystemExit):
        print('\n! Received keyboard interrupt, quitting haptic touch play\n')


if __name__ == '__main__':
18    main()

title: Force Feedback example
text:
Intro
This web page provides a comprehensive guide on how to use the Force Feedback feature of the Teslasuit device. The page is structured to help developers understand the process of initializing the Teslasuit API, connecting to a device, configuring force feedback parameters, and enabling/disabling force feedback.

title: Force Feedback example
text:
Code for Force Feedback

import time
1from teslasuit_sdk import ts_api
2from teslasuit_sdk.ts_mapper import TsBone2dIndex
3from teslasuit_sdk.subsystems.ts_magnetic_encoder import (
    TsForceFeedbackLockDirection, TsForceFeedbackConfig)

def main():
    try:
4        print("Initialize API")
        api = ts_api.TsApi()

5        print("Waiting for a Teslasuit device to connect...")
        device = api.get_device_manager().get_or_wait_last_device_attached()

6        print("Accessing the Magnetic Encoder subsystem...")
        encoder = device.magnetic_encoder

7        print("Set force feedback angle")
        ff_config = [TsForceFeedbackConfig()]
        ff_config[0].bone_index = TsBone2dIndex.RightThumbProximal.value
        ff_config[0].angle = 45
        ff_config[0].hardness_percent = 100
        ff_config[0].lock_direction = TsForceFeedbackLockDirection.Both.value
8        encoder.ts_force_feedback_enable(ff_config)

9        time.sleep(10)
10        print("Release force feedback")
        encoder.ts_force_feedback_disable([TsBone2dIndex.RightThumbProximal.value])
11        print("Finished")

12    except (KeyboardInterrupt, SystemExit):
        print('\n! Received keyboard interrupt, quitting glove forcefeedback\n')

13main()

1

Import the main Teslasuit API module.

2

Import the bone index mapper for specifying bones.

3

Import the force feedback configuration and lock direction classes.

4

Initialize the Teslasuit API.

5

Wait for a Teslasuit device to connect.

6

Access the Magnetic Encoder subsystem of the connected device.

7

Configure force feedback parameters, including bone index, angle, hardness, and lock direction.

8

Enable force feedback using the configured parameters.

9

Wait for 10 seconds to observe the force feedback effect.

10

Disable force feedback for the specified bone index.

11

Print a message indicating the process is finished.

12

Handle keyboard interrupts gracefully.

13

Start the program using the main function.

title: Getting started
text:
Welcome to the Teslasuit API! This guide will help you take your first steps with the Teslasuit API ‚Äî from setting up your environment to running your first haptic interaction.
Make sure your Teslasuit is connected to your PC or laptop before continuing.

title: Getting started
text:
Requirements
To get started, make sure the following requirements are met:

Teslasuit device connected and recognized by the system
Teslasuit Control Center installed (for suit calibration)
Teslasuit SDK added to your PATH

title: Getting started
text:
Environment Setup
Before writing any code, make sure the Teslasuit SDK is available in your Python environment.
If you‚Äôre developing locally and the SDK is not in your PATH, you can use the following snippet to add it dynamically:
try:
    import teslasuit_sdk
except ImportError:
    import os
    import sys
    sdk_path = os.path.abspath(os.path.join(os.path.dirname(__file__), '..'))
    sys.path.insert(0, sdk_path)
    import teslasuit_sdk
    print(f'Successfully added \'{sdk_path}\' into sys.path')

title: Getting started
text:
First steps

Connect the Suit
After connecting your Teslasuit to your PC or laptop, you‚Äôre ready to explore its capabilities using Python.
To begin, you need to:

Attach the device
Initialize the API and Device
Create a haptic playable

‚ö†Ô∏è Safety First!  Please calibrate your suit in Control Center in order to avoid unpleasant or painful experience


Run Your First Touch
Below is a complete example that demonstrates how to send a basic haptic touch to the right upper arm of the suit:
import time
from teslasuit_sdk import ts_api
import teslasuit_sdk.subsystems.ts_haptic
from teslasuit_sdk.ts_mapper import TsBone2dIndex

TOUCH_DURATION_MS = 1000

def main():
    print("Initialize API")
    api = ts_api.TsApi()
    device = api.get_device_manager().get_or_wait_last_device_attached()
    player = device.haptic
    mapper = api.mapper

    print("Setup channels to play and touch parameters")
    layout = mapper.get_haptic_electric_channel_layout(device.get_mapping())
    bones = mapper.get_layout_bones(layout)
    channels = mapper.get_bone_contents(bones[TsBone2dIndex.RightUpperArm.value])
    params = player.create_touch_parameters(100, 40, 150)

    print("Create touch and play")
    playable_id = player.create_touch(params, channels, TOUCH_DURATION_MS)
    player.play_playable(playable_id)

    print("Wait until playback finished...")
    time.sleep(TOUCH_DURATION_MS / 1000)
    print("Finished")


if __name__ == '__main__':
    main()

title: Getting started
text:
Test Your Setup
If the suit is connected and the SDK is installed correctly, running the script above should produce a short haptic effect on the right upper arm of the suit.
If nothing happens:
Ensure the device is calibrated in the Control Center Check the connection Confirm that Python can import the teslasuit_sdk module

title: EMG
text:
Intro
The EMG subsystem provides functionality to access and process Electromyography (EMG) data from Teslasuit devices.

title: EMG
text:
Prerequisites

Teslasuit API Initialization
The Teslasuit API must be initialized before accessing any of its features.
Connected Teslasuit Device
A Teslasuit device must be connected. If no device is available, the system will wait until one is attached.
Access to the EMG Subsystem
The TsEmg class is part of the device‚Äôs functionality and can only be used after obtaining access to a connected Teslasuit device.


Note:
Since TsEmg is a member of the device class, it cannot be used independently without an active Teslasuit device.

title: EMG
text:
Class TsEmg
Provides an interface for interacting with the Teslasuit EMG subsystem.
This class allows for streaming EMG data, setting filter options, and retrieving raw EMG data.

Class methods:

set_options(self, lower_bandwidth, upper_bandwidth, sample_frequency, sample_size)
Set options for EMG streaming, such as filter parameters.
Args:
lower_bandwidth (int): Filter‚Äôs lower bandwidth.
upper_bandwidth (int): Filter‚Äôs upper bandwidth.
sample_frequency (int): Sampling frequency.
sample_size (int): Sample size.

start_streaming(self)
Start EMG streaming for a provided device handle.
This method subscribes to the data update callbacks and starts the streaming process.

stop_streaming(self)
Stop EMG streaming for a provided device handle.
This method unsubscribes from the data update callbacks and stops the streaming process.

get_data_on_ready(self)
Wait until EMG data is ready and retrieve it.
This method blocks until data is available or streaming is stopped.
Returns:
TsEmgData: The latest EMG data object containing information about nodes, channels, and timestamps.

title: Mocap
text:
Class TsPpg
Provides an interface for interacting with the Teslasuit motion capture (mocap) subsystem.
This class allows for streaming motion capture data, retrieving raw sensor data, skeleton data for individual bones, and calibration.

Class methods:

start_streaming(self)
Start mocap streaming for a provided device handle.
This method subscribes to the raw data and skeleton data update callbacks and starts the streaming process.

stop_streaming(self)
Stop mocap streaming for a provided device handle.
This method unsubscribes from the raw data and skeleton data update callbacks and stops the streaming process.

calibrate_skeleton(self)
Calibrate mocap skeleton model.
This method triggers the calibration process for the skeleton model to ensure accurate motion capture data.

get_raw_data_on_ready(self)
Wait until raw mocap data is ready and retrieve it.
This method blocks until raw data is available or streaming is stopped.
Returns:
dict: A dictionary containing raw sensor data for all bones in format of TsMocapSensor structure.

get_skeleton_data_on_ready(self)
Wait until skeleton mocap data is ready and retrieve it.
This method blocks until skeleton data is available or streaming is stopped.
Returns:
dict: A dictionary containing skeleton data for all bones in format of TsMocapBone structure.

get_biomechanical_angles_on_ready(self)
Wait until biomechanical angles data is ready and retrieve it.
This method blocks until biomechanical angles data is available or streaming is stopped.
Returns:
dict: A dictionary containing biomechanical angles for all bones in format ‚ÄòTsBiomechanicalIndex‚Äô: angle value.

title: Data structures
text: This is the page where you can find explanation of data structures used in TESLASUIT SDK.

title: Data structures
text:
PPG

TsHrv(Structure):
Represents Heart Rate Variability (HRV) metrics.
This structure stores various HRV parameters, which are used to analyze fluctuations in heart rate over time. These metrics help assess autonomic nervous system activity and overall heart health.
Attributes:
mean_rr (float): Mean RR interval (time between successive heartbeats) in milliseconds.

sdnn (float): Standard deviation of NN (normal-to-normal) intervals, indicating overall HRV.

sdsd (float): Standard deviation of successive RR interval differences.

rmssd (float): Root Mean Square of Successive Differences between RR intervals, 
                reflecting short-term HRV.

sd1 (float): Poincar√© plot standard deviation perpendicular to the line of identity 
                (short-term HRV component).

sd2 (float): Poincar√© plot standard deviation along the line of identity 
                (long-term HRV component).

hlf (float): High-frequency component of HRV, associated with parasympathetic nervous activity.


TsPpgRawData(Structure):
Represents raw PPG (Photoplethysmography) data from multiple sensor nodes.
This structure holds raw PPG data collected from multiple sensor nodes, each of which contains infrared, red, blue, and green sensor values, along with timestamps.
Attributes: number_of_nodes (int): The number of sensor nodes providing PPG data. nodes (POINTER(TsPpgRawNodeData)): Pointer to an array of node data structures.


TsPpgData(Structure):
Represents processed PPG (Photoplethysmography) data from multiple sensor nodes.
This structure stores processed PPG data collected from multiple sensor nodes. Each node contains PPG-related metrics, including heart rate validation.
Attributes: number_of_nodes (int): The number of sensor nodes providing PPG data. nodes (POINTER(TsPpgNodeData)): Pointer to an array of processed node data structures.


TsPpgNodeData(Structure):
Represents processed PPG (Photoplethysmography) data for a single sensor node. This structure stores heart rate, blood oxygen level, and validity flags for a specific PPG sensor node, along with a timestamp indicating when the data was recorded. Attributes: heart_rate (int): Heart rate calculated in BPM. oxygen_percent (int): The measured blood oxygen saturation (SpO2) percentage. is_heart_rate_valid (bool): Is calculated heart rate valid. is_oxygen_percent_valid (bool): Is blood oxygen value valid. timestamp (int): Time point that set when the last raw PPG data sample was processed.

title: Data structures
text:
Mocap

TsVec2f(Structure):
Represents a 2D vector with float coordinates.
Attributes: x (float): X coordinate. y (float): Y coordinate.



TsVec3f(Structure):
Represents a 3D vector with float coordinates.
Attributes: x (float): X coordinate. y (float): Y coordinate. z (float): Z coordinate.



TsQuat(Structure):
Represents a quaternion for 3D rotation.
Attributes: w (float): Rotation component. x (float): X coordinate. y (float): Y coordinate. z (float): Z coordinate.



TsMocapBone(Structure):
Represents skeleton bone data.
Attributes: position (TsVec3f): Position of the bone. rotation (TsQuat): Rotation of the bone.



TsMocapSensor(Structure):
Represents raw IMU sensor data.
Attributes: q6 (TsQuat): 6-axis Quaternion data (without magnetometer). q9 (TsQuat): 9-axis Quaternion data (q6 including magnetometer). accel (TsVec3f): Accelerometer data. gyro (TsVec3f): Gyroscope data. magn (TsVec3f): Magnetometer data. linear_accel (TsVec3f): Linear acceleration data. timestamp (uint64): Timestamp of the data.

title: Data structures
text:
EMG

TsEmgOptions(Structure):
Represents EMG filter options.
Attributes: lower_bandwidth (int): Filter‚Äôs lower bandwidth.
upper_bandwidth (int): Filter‚Äôs upper bandwidth.
sampling_frequency (int): Sampling frequency.
sample_size (int): Sample size.



TsEmgChannelData(Structure):
Represents EMG channel data.
Attributes: channel_index (int): Index of the channel.
number_of_samples (int): Number of samples in the channel.
samples (list): List of samples.



TsEmgNodeData(Structure):
Represents EMG node data.
Attributes: node_index (int): Index of the node.
number_of_channels (int): Number of channels in the node.
channels (list): List of TsEmgChannelData objects.
number_of_timestamps (int): Number of timestamps.
timestamps (list): List of timestamps.



TsEmgData(Structure):
Represents EMG data.
Attributes: number_of_nodes (int): Number of nodes.
nodes (list): List of TsEmgNodeData objects.
options (TsEmgOptions): EMG options.

title: Data structures
text:
Haptic

TsHapticParam(Structure):
Represents a haptic parameter.
Attributes: - type (TsHapticParamType): Type of the parameter (e.g., Period, Amplitude, PulseWidth).
- value (float): Value of the parameter.



TsHapticParamMultiplier(Structure):
Represents a multiplier for haptic parameters.
Attributes: - type (TsHapticParamType): Type of the parameter (e.g., Period, Amplitude, PulseWidth).
- value (float): Multiplier value (between 0 and 1).



TsHapticParamType(Enum):
Enumeration of haptic parameter types.
Values: - Undefined: Undefined parameter type.
- Period: Period parameter.
- Amplitude: Amplitude parameter.
- PulseWidth: Pulse width parameter.
- Temperature: Temperature parameter.



TsHapticPlayer(Structure):
Represents the Haptic Player for managing haptic feedback.
Attributes: - playables (list): List of active haptic playables.
- is_running (bool): Indicates if the player is running.
- is_paused (bool): Indicates if the player is paused.
- is_muted (bool): Indicates if the player is muted.

title: Data structures
text:
Magnetic Encoder

TsMagneticEncoderConfig(Structure):
Represents the configuration for servomotor magnetic encoder.
Attributes:
- bone_index (int): Index of the bone.
- angle (float): Angle for the magnetic encoder.
- hardness_percent (int): Hardness percentage from 0 to 100.
- lock_direction ([TsMagneticEncoderLockDirection](#tsmagneticencoderlockdirection)): Direction of the lock.



TsMagneticEncoderLockDirection(Enum):
Enumeration of magnetic encoder lock directions.
Values:
- Up: Lock movement upwards.
- Down: Lock movement downwards.
- Both: Lock movement in both directions.



TsFingerMEPosition(Class):
Represents the position of a finger.
Attributes:
- flexion_angle (float): Flexion angle of the finger.
- abduction_angle (float): Abduction angle of the finger.



TsGloveMEPosition(Class):
Represents the magnetic encoder position structures for the fingers.
Attributes:
- side (TsDeviceSide): Side of the glove (left or right).
- fingers (dict): Dictionary of bone indexes and their corresponding TsFingerMEPosition.

title: Haptic
text:
Class TsHapticPlayer
Handles haptic feedback management, including creating and controlling haptic playables and instant touches.

Class methods:

is_player_running(self)
Checks if the haptic player is currently running.
Returns:
bool: True if the player is running.

stop_player(self)
Stops the haptic player for the connected device.

is_player_paused(self)
Checks if the haptic player is in a paused state.
Returns:
bool: True if the player is paused.

set_player_paused(self, is_paused)
Pauses or resumes the haptic player.
Parameters:
- is_paused (bool): True to pause, False to resume.

is_player_muted(self)
Checks if the haptic player is muted.
Returns:
bool: True if the player is muted.

set_player_muted(self, is_muted)
Mutes or unmutes the haptic player.
Parameters:
- is_muted (bool): True to mute, False to unmute.

get_player_time(self)
Retrieves the time elapsed since the haptic player started.
Returns:
int: Time in milliseconds.

create_playable(self, asset, is_looped)
Creates a playable from a haptic asset.
Parameters:
- asset: The haptic asset.
- is_looped (bool): Whether the playable should loop.
Returns:
int: The ID of the created playable.

play_playable(self, playable_id)
Plays a haptic playable by its ID.
Parameters:
- playable_id (int): The ID of the playable.

play_touch(self, params, channels, duration)
Plays an instant haptic touch with the specified parameters.
Parameters:
- params (list): List of TsHapticParam objects.
- channels (list): List of channel IDs.
- duration (int): Duration in milliseconds.

stop_playable(self, playable_id)
Stops a haptic playable by its ID.
Parameters:
- playable_id (int): The ID of the playable.

remove_playable(self, playable_id)
Removes a haptic playable from the player.
Parameters:
- playable_id (int): The ID of the playable.

clear_all_playables(self)
Removes all haptic playables from the haptic player.

create_touch_parameters(self, period_ms, amplitude, pulse_width)
Creates parameters for an instant haptic touch.
Parameters:
- period_ms (float): Period in milliseconds.
- amplitude (float): Amplitude value.
- pulse_width (float): Pulse width value.
Returns:
list: List of TsHapticParam objects.

create_touch_multipliers(self, period_ms_m, amplitude_m, pulse_width_m)
Creates multipliers for an instant haptic touch.
Parameters:
- period_ms_m (float): Period multiplier.
- amplitude_m (float): Amplitude multiplier.
- pulse_width_m (float): Pulse width multiplier.
Returns:
list: List of TsHapticParamMultiplier objects.

title: PPG
text:
Class TsPpg
Handles PPG (Photoplethysmography) sensor data processing and streaming. This class manages the interaction with a PPG sensor, including raw and processed data streaming, calibration, and retrieving heart rate variability (HRV) and raw PPG data.

Class methods:

start_raw_streaming(self)
Start the streaming of a PPG raw data

stop_raw_streaming(self)
Stop the streaming of a PPG raw data

get_hrv_data_on_ready(self)
Blocks execution until HRV data is ready and returns the latest HRV data.
Returns TsHrv (struct): The latest HRV data.

get_raw_data_on_ready(self)
Blocks execution until raw PPG data is ready and returns the latest raw data. Returns TsPpgRawData (struct): The latest raw PPG data.

get_hrv(self)
Retrieves the latest HRV data. Returns TsHrv (struct): The latest HRV data.

get_data_raw(self)
Retrieves the latest raw PPG data. Returns TsPpgRawData (struct): The latest raw PPG data.

get_data(self)
Retrieves the latest processed PPG data. Returns TsPpgData: The latest processed PPG data.
NB! TsPpgData struct doesn‚Äôt provide any parameters such as ‚Äúheart_rate‚Äù or ‚Äúoxygen_percent‚Äù. The access is given through the TsPpgNodeData struct. Please see the example.

calibrate(self)
Calibrates PPG processor. The calibration procedure is capturing interval of the raw data during 3 seconds. The captured interval will be used in calculation of all ppg parameters. By default, calibration procedure starts on starting PPG processor. In case on bad start, the calibration procedure might be restarted using this function.

Connected Teslasuit Device
A Teslasuit device must be connected. If no device is available, the system will wait until one is attached.

Access to the Magnetic Encoder Subsystem
The Magnetic Encoder subsystem can only be used after obtaining access to a connected Teslasuit device.


Note:
Magnetic Encoder functionality is tied to the device class and cannot be used independently without an active Teslasuit device.

title: Introduction
text:
The Teslasuit SDK is a developer toolkit for integrating the Teslasuit ‚Äî a full-body haptic suit with motion capture and biometric sensors ‚Äî into immersive applications. With this SDK, developers can control the suit‚Äôs haptic feedback system, stream and record motion data, and monitor biometric signals in real time.
The Teslasuit SDK Python API provides a high-level interface for integrating Teslasuit systems into Python-based applications. It enables developers, researchers, and engineers to access the full range of Teslasuit‚Äôs haptic, motion capture, and biometric capabilities through an efficient and extensible API.





The Haptics module allows you to control the suit‚Äôs network of electrical stimulators to create realistic tactile feedback or stimulate major muscle groups to elicit contractions. Developers can configure custom stimulation patterns, adjust intensity levels, and trigger feedback events in sync with application logic.
For example, you might simulate the feeling of impact or rainfall on the user‚Äôs body, or provide a complex stimulation pattern across multiple muscle groups in the lower extremities, synchronized with the gait cycle.
‚û°Ô∏è Create your first haptic touch.
üîç Learn more about the suit‚Äôs EMS system and best practices for designing haptic feedback here.




The Motion Capture module provides access to the suit‚Äôs built-in IMU-based inertial tracking system. The SDK streams detailed motion and biomechanical data in real time, using a skeletal model to deliver full-body pose tracking.
For example, you can animate a game character using real-time body motion, record physical activity for replay or analysis, or dynamically adjust stimulation based on biomechanical feedback.
‚û°Ô∏è Start your first motion capture stream.
üîç Learn more about Teslasuit‚Äôs MoCap system, coordinate systems, and best practices here.




The Biometry module provides real-time biometric readings from the suit‚Äôs sensors to monitor the user‚Äôs physical state. With the Python API, developers can access data such as heart rate and heart rate variability (HRV), offering insights into stress, fatigue, or exertion levels.
For instance, an adaptive training application can adjust difficulty or feedback based on a user‚Äôs physiological response.
‚û°Ô∏è Measure your heart rate now.
üîç Learn more about Teslasuit‚Äôs biometric system and HRV metrics here.





The API documentation is organized into the following sections:

Getting Started ‚Äì Fast setup for quick first steps
Main Concepts ‚Äì Theory and architecture of Teslasuit systems

API Reference

Core ‚Äì Initialization, connection, session control

Subsystems ‚Äì Haptics, Mocap, Biometry, Mapping, etc.


Examples ‚Äì Step-by-step usage scripts

Use Cases ‚Äì Practical applications and integration flows





To use the Teslasuit SDK Python API, ensure you have:

Windows 10 or later

Installed Teslasuit Control Center
Python 3.8 or higher

A connected Teslasuit device





For technical inquiries, feature requests, or troubleshooting assistance, please contact:

Help Desk

FAQ

Intro
This web page provides a comprehensive guide on how to retrieve data from the EMG (Electromyography) sensor of a Teslasuit device. The page is structured to help developers understand the process of initializing the Teslasuit API, connecting to a device, accessing the EMG subsystem, and streaming data.

title: EMG example
text:
Code for EMG data
1from teslasuit_sdk import ts_api

def main():
2    print("Initializing Teslasuit API...")
    api = ts_api.TsApi()

3    print("Waiting for a Teslasuit device to connect...")
    device = api.get_device_manager().get_or_wait_last_device_attached()

4    print("Accessing the EMG subsystem...")
    emg = device.emg

5    print("Starting EMG data streaming...")
    emg.start_streaming()

    desired_fps = 60
    period_in_ms = 1. / desired_fps
    frames_to_stream = 10

    print("Streaming EMG data...")
6    while frames_to_stream:
        time.sleep(period_in_ms)
7        print("EMG data:", emg)
        frames_to_stream -= 1

    print("Stopping EMG data streaming...")
8    emg.stop_streaming()
9    print("Finished")

# Entry point for the script
if __name__ == "__main__":
10    main()

Code for Mocap data
1from teslasuit_sdk import ts_api
2import teslasuit_sdk.subsystems.ts_mocap
3from teslasuit_sdk.ts_mapper import (TsBone2dIndex, TsBiomechanicalIndex)

def main():
4    is_streaming = False
    try:
5        print("Initializing Teslasuit API...")
        api = ts_api.TsApi()

6        print("Waiting for a Teslasuit device to connect...")
        device = api.get_device_manager().get_or_wait_last_device_attached()

7        print("Accessing the Mocap subsystem...")
        mocap = device.mocap

8        print("Starting Mocap data streaming...")
        mocap.start_streaming()
        is_streaming = True

        frames = 100
9        while frames > 0:
10            data = mocap.get_raw_data_on_ready()
            print("Bone data:", data[TsBone2dIndex.RightUpperArm])
11            biomech_data = mocap.get_biomechanical_angles_on_ready()
            print("Biomech Pelvis Tilt: ", biomech_data[TsBiomechanicalIndex.PelvisTilt])
12            frames -= 1

13        print("Finished")

14    except (KeyboardInterrupt, SystemExit):
        print('\n! Received keyboard interrupt, quitting mocap streaming\n')

15    if is_streaming:
        mocap.stop_streaming()
        print("Mocap streaming was stopped")

if __name__ == '__main__':
16    main()

To start we need





To start working with the Teslasuit PPG sensor, you need to ensure the following prerequisites are met:

Teslasuit Device

Teslasuit SDK

Install the Teslasuit SDK.

Follow the installation guide to set up the SDK on your system.

Python Environment

Install Python 3.8 or higher.
Ensure that Python SDK is added to your . If it‚Äôs not run script from this section

Connection Setup

Ensure the Teslasuit device is powered on and connected to your computer via WiFi.
Verify the connection using the Teslasuit Control Center application.

Development Environment

Use an IDE or text editor that supports Python development, such as VS Code or PyCharm.

Permissions

Ensure you have the necessary permissions to access the Teslasuit device and its subsystems.

On some systems, you may need to run the script with elevated privileges.


Once these prerequisites are met, you can proceed to initialize the Teslasuit API and start working with the PPG subsystem as demonstrated in the code section below.

title: Real-time heart rate visualiser
text:
Visualising heart rate data
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
1from teslasuit_sdk import ts_api
2import teslasuit_sdk.subsystems.ts_ppg


def main():
3    print("Initializing Teslasuit API...")
    api = ts_api.TsApi()

4    print("Waiting for a Teslasuit device to connect...")
    device = api.get_device_manager().get_or_wait_last_device_attached()

5    print("Accessing the PPG subsystem...")
    ppg = device.ppg

6    print("Starting raw PPG data streaming...")
    ppg.start_raw_streaming()

    # Initialize plot
7    plt.ion()
    fig, ax = plt.subplots()
    x_data, y_data = [], []
    line, = ax.plot(x_data, y_data, label="Heart Rate (bpm)")
    ax.set_xlabel("Timestamp (s)")
    ax.set_ylabel("Heart Rate (bpm)")
    ax.set_title("Real-Time Heart Rate Data")
    ax.legend()

8    print("Waiting for Heart Rate data...")

    try:
        while True:
            # Get processed PPG data
9            node_data = ppg.get_data()
            heart_rate = node_data.nodes[0].heart_rate
            timestamp = node_data.nodes[0].timestamp

            # Update data
10            x_data.append(timestamp)
            y_data.append(heart_rate)

            # Update plot
11            line.set_xdata(x_data)
            line.set_ydata(y_data)
            ax.relim()
            ax.autoscale_view()
            plt.draw()
            plt.pause(0.01)

12    except KeyboardInterrupt:
        print("Stopping real-time plotting...")
    finally:
13        ppg.stop_raw_streaming()
        plt.ioff()
        plt.show()

if __name__ == "__main__":
14    main()

2

Import the PPG subsystem: Import the PPG subsystem from the SDK.

5

Access the PPG subsystem: Access the PPG subsystem from the connected device.

6

Start raw PPG data streaming: Start streaming raw PPG data from the suit.

7

Initialize the real-time plot: Set up the matplotlib plot for real-time visualization of heart rate data.

8

Start waiting for heart rate data: Begin the loop to process and visualize heart rate data.

9

Retrieve heart rate data: Get processed PPG data and extract the heart rate and timestamp.

10

Update data arrays: Append the timestamp and heart rate to the respective data arrays.

11

Update the plot: Update the plot with the new data and refresh the visualization.

12

Handle keyboard interrupt: Gracefully stop the program when interrupted (e.g., via Ctrl+C).

13

Stop raw PPG data streaming: Stop the PPG data stream and close the plot.

14

Run the main function: Start the program using the main function.








Potential problems and solutions






Device Connection Issues

Problem: The Teslasuit device may not connect or be detected by the API.

Solution: Ensure the device is powered on and within range. Verify that the Teslasuit drivers and SDK are correctly installed. Check for any connection errors in the logs.

PPG Subsystem Not Accessible

Problem: The PPG subsystem might not be available or initialized properly.

Solution: Confirm that the connected Teslasuit device supports the PPG subsystem. Restart the device and reinitialize the API if necessary. Double-check that the Teslasuit version is 4.7 or higher, as earlier versions may not support the PPG functionality.

SDK Initialization Issues

Problem: The SDK cannot be initialized, or the library is not found.

Solution: Verify that the Teslasuit SDK is installed correctly. Refer to the installation guide for instructions. Ensure the environment of the working project is properly set up. Refer to the this section for details.

Data Streaming Delays

Problem: There may be delays in receiving HRV or heart rate data.

Solution: Delays could be caused by the algorithm behind HRV calculation. Usually it requires at least 30 second of raw data to calculate HRV.
